title: What made the 1971 album “Tapestry” by Carole King such a phenomenal album? Did it influence other artists in that genre? - Quora

response.answer_text: Carole was a main female voice of the more serious singer-songwriter side of popular music. I’m sorry if this answer is a little disorganized but my thoughts about this are complicated. The main reason for that is Carole already had had a big career as a songwriter, and that dramatically affected the album and its success. First, Tapestry came out at the right time. James Taylor’s huge hit with Fire & Rain the year before exposed a large audience existed for popular music that didnt sound poppy. Note: Sugar Sugar by the non-group The Archies may have been the top selling song of 1969. (And also note: the Monkees turned down one of the most successful songs of all time because it was too commercial. Keep that in mind.) How big was the vogue? Again, James Taylor took Carole’s song You’ve Got A Friend to his first #1 in I think the same year, 1971. Think about that: James recorded the same song Carole has on her own record. The song really is that good. As for other examples, think Laura Nyro: similar tonality in voice, wrote hits like Wedding Bell Blues (for the 5th Dimension), Eli’s Comin’ (3 Dog Night), And When I Die (for BST) in the years immediately preceding Tapestry. She recorded her own material but it was as a songwriter that she’s best remembered. And of course there was Aretha. Who first sang Carole and Gerry Goffin’s You Make Me Feel Like A Natural Woman, back in 1967. So Carole could see a pathway she could go down, and as a songwriter in that era it was relatively normal for her to record her own material. Second, Carole took some of her best for herself. And some great stuff by Goffin/King & Stern/King (notably both Where You Lead, which became the theme for Gilmore Girls and It’s Too Late). As a top songwriter in the business, she knew a good song. This was not a case where the artist had to be persuaded to sing a song with commercial potential or maybe just convinced of the merits of a song. Carole had lived that for years. She and Gerry wrote Pleasant Valley Sunday. They go back to Little Eva and the Loco-Motion and Herman’s Hermits doing I’m Into Something Good. She’d already had a massive career before she started doing her own music. So, there were antecedents, including Carole’s own work. And there was a vibe that the marketplace was buying softer music that had the energy of rock music without the noise and which wasnt syrupy or, bluntly, dumb as Sugar, Sugar’s lyrics. And she nailed it. She totally nailed it. That record was so good that it quickly became one of those ‘if you dont like Tapestry, there’s something wrong with you’ records. Even back in those relatively unenlightened days, men dug the idea of women’s sexuality in I Feel The Earth Move. The biggest male chauvinist of that era had to respect Tapestry. And the appeal to women was unreal. Carole unlocked women’s souls.

American singer/songwriter Carol King released the album “ Tapestry” back in 1971. It has been one of the top selling albums of all time selling over 25 million copies. The album simply had some amazing songs on it as demonstrated by the success of the album over time.  The album garnered four Grammy awards in 1972 and was named Album of The Year. Rolling Stone magazine listed the song at # 25 in the list of 500 Greatest albums of all time. It was at top of the charts for 15 weeks straight and to this day the album holds the record for the most consecutive weeks by a female artist at the top of the charts. Numerous artists have covered the music of Carol King, with noteables such as James Taylor covering “ You’ve Got a Friend”, Barbara Streisand doing "Where You Lead" Several tribute albums done by numerous artists have been produced the first being “Tapestry Revisited: A Tribute to Carole King” and followed by “ A New Tapestry – Carole King Tribute” . Australian recording artist Marcia Hines recorded a tribute album, “Marcia Sings Tapestry” in 2010. The album has proved itself to be a proven success and Carole King did indeed influence many other musicians through her music. She is an part of musical history in a very large way.

Wednesday, September 30, 2020. The Question: What made the 1971 album “Tapestry” by Carole King such a phenomenal album? Did it influence other artists in that genre? bala Ramakrishnan (bR)’s Answer: This was one of the first albums I bought in my life (after buying all the albums by The Beatles). (NOTE: I came to the United States in 1971). “Tapestry” is filled with absolutely wonderful songs. Here is one for you to listen to as you continue reading…  Carole King - It's Too Late (Audio) This From Wikipedia… The album was critically well-received; Village Voice critic Robert Christgau felt that her voice, free of "technical decorum", would liberate female singers; while Jon Landau in Rolling Stone felt that King was one of the most creative pop music figures and had created an album of "surpassing personal-intimacy and musical accomplishment". Along with being selected Album of the Year, it also received Grammys for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance, Record of the Year ("It's Too Late"), and Song of the Year ("You've Got a Friend"), making King the first solo female artist to win the Grammy Award for Record of the Year, and the first woman to win the Grammy Award for Song of the Year. The album remained on the Billboard charts for 313 weeks (second only to Pink Floyd's 724 weeks with The Dark Side of the Moon).

I will try to be as brief as possible. 1) great melodic songs. 2) No complicated dressing up with arrangements . In fact as a musician and writer my first reaction was that theLP was rather like a demo, even though it required no other thing in order to improve it. 3)It was all about the songs . Carole had split with her husband who wrote lyrics with her and she was sort of forced to perform the new songs which were more personal and mature. Consequently, there existed a ready made collection of songs which tasteful singers jumped upon, to be done as in days gone by, in different ways.Nothing I have said is meant in any way, to lessen the excellent performances on these recordings !So Intentionally or by circumstance,Carole came up with something that cried out for dissemination of the material by others. In other words it was the complete opposite of a pop record that was an end in itself. Tapestry was a wonderful thing and a jumping off point for inspired others.Since then,it had not inspired anyone to attempt to mimic Carole. It is the song not the singer.

I believe the timeless themes of love, hope, frustration and the like are what makes albums like ‘Tapestry’ such enduring and influential recordings. When songwriters are enduring personal tragedy or disappointments in life or career, these can translate into amazing testaments, musically speaking. Take ‘Rumours’ by Fleetwood Mac, which was written under extreme emotional duress between the band members, as an example. It’s popular longevity in the Billboard Top 200 albums for many years shows that it connected with it’s audience in a big way. Previous to that, ‘Tapestry’ had held that record. Variety of song styles and mood on ‘Tapestry’ makes it a huge influence on many musicians. However, all of these timeless themes mean nothing unless the music can hook you and/or move you. That, is the crux of the biscuit.

First, Ms King is a phenomenal songwriter. Her somgs for the album were some of her finest. second, right place at the right time. She unveiled Tapestry when singer/ songwriters were popular (Denver, Taylor, Nyro, Simon et al). To invoke Graham Nash, she invited you into her living room for a quiet concert. Her influence opened the door for many artists.

My girl friend loved Carole King back in the 70’s. It was a time of change for her and the songs related to her life of ups and downs. I’m sure there were countless women that her music influenced and loved to hear it. Whenever I hear songs off that album I think of her and our time together back then. She has been gone 7 years now.

Carol King had been writing hit songs for a decade before she recorded her own album. Many people didn`t realize how many hit songs she had written with her husband Gerry Goffin. She did a few on Tapestry, and added some new songs, it was almost a perfect album. Carol is a very talented lady, and generations of listeners are grateful for her talents, and yes she definitely influenced many song writers and performers, with her talent
The pure quality of the songwriting. It was a huge influence on her peers and contemporaries as well as the next generation of songwriters

I have that cd in my car and it’s a reminder of what a ‘great’ singer/songwriter should be: Someone who can serenely influence those who can feel the earth move or can take the journey up on the roof.
